column1: Tønsberg is generally regarded as the oldest city in Norway
column2: founded by Vikings in the 9th century. Tønsberg was established as a municipality on 1 January 1838 (see formannskapsdistrikt). The rural municipality of Sem was merged into the municipality of Tønsberg on 1 January 1988. The neighboring municipality of Re was merged into Tønsberg on 1 January 2020.It is home to Tønsberg Fortress on Castle Mountain
column3: which includes ruins from Castrum Tunsbergis
column4: Norway's largest castle in the 13th century. An outdoor music festival is held at Tønsberg Fortress every July. Tønsberg is also home of Oseberg Mound
column5: where the 9th-century Oseberg Ship was excavated.

column1: The Old Norse form of the name was Túnsberg. The first element is the genitive case of tún (n)
column2: meaning fenced area or garden.  The last element is berg (n)
column3: meaning mountain. The name originally referred to the fortifications on Slottsfjellet. The old spelling has been retained in the name of the diocese

column1: The coat of arms is an old city seal from as far back as 1349. The seal shows Tønsberg Fortress surrounded by a ring wall on a mountain with the sea in front. There is also a longship in the water in front of the fortress. Around the seal are the words (in Latin): This is the seal of Tunsberg.
Tønsberg is the oldest city in Norway
column2: founded by Harald Fairhair in the 9th century. It was also an ancient capital of Norway. The first time the town was mentioned by a contemporary writer was in 1130. According to Snorri Sturluson
column3: Tønsberg was founded before the Battle of Hafrsfjord
column6: took place in 871. What year the battle took place is disputed
column8: and most current historians believe the battle took place closer to 900. However
column9: if the battle did in fact take place in 871
column10: this would make Tønsberg one of the oldest present Scandinavian cities.  It was based upon this that the city's 1000 years jubilee was celebrated in 1871
column11: and 1100 years jubilee in 1971. The archaeological excavations conducted in 1987–88 underneath the monastery ruins revealed several Viking graves which have served to confirm the earlier age of the original settlement.The king or his ombudsman resided in the old Royal Court at  Sæheimr

column1: The center of the world's modern whaling industry was concentrated in Tønsberg and neighboring Sandefjord. Tønsberg along with neighboring Sandefjord and Larvik were dominant whaling towns in Norway. While whalers from Sandefjord established the first whaling station in the Faroe Islands
column2: whalers from Tønsberg initiated whaling in Iceland and the Hebrides.During the 1850s
column3: Tønsberg turned into a base of operation and source of expertise for whalers in the Arctic- and Antarctic Oceans. Tønsberg has been called “the cradle of modern whaling. In the 1892 publication “Handbook for Travellers in Norway” by John Murray
column4: Tønsberg is described as “the centre of the Norwegian whaling and sealing industries in the Arctic Ocean.”The first whaling ventures to Antarctica was led by engineer Henrik Henriksen of Tønsberg. Henrik Johan Bull was another famous whaler from the district
column5: famous for his expeditions to Antarctica. Bull traveled from Australia to Tønsberg in order to learn from local whaler Svend Foyn
column6: who is recognized as the pioneer of the modern whaling industry.One of the city's most prominent residents
column8: was a pioneer who embarked on an 1847 expedition to the Arctic
column9: which led to a catch of 6
column10: 000 seals. Soon Tønsberg Harbor was home to a large fleet of sealing vessels
column11: and the sealing industry grew further after the 1849 repeal of Britain's Navigation Acts. The hunters turned the seals to near extinction in the Arctic Ocean
column12: and therefore turned to Bottle-nosed whales during the 1870s. Norway maintained a monopoly on European whaling until 1883
column13: first and foremost due to Svend Foyn's patent rights to whaling techniques and inventions. Over-hunting in the Arctic eventually drove the whalers to Antarctica. By the beginning of the 20th century
column14: Tønsberg had lost its preeminence in the whaling industry to the neighboring city of Sandefjord. Sandefjord
column15: which lies just south of Tønsberg
column16: later became known as the world's whaling capital.

column4: created when the counties of Buskerud and Vestfold og Telemark were separated from the Diocese of Oslo.

column1: Tønsberg is a city and municipality in Vestfold County

column3: south of Horten

column5: the municipality is also home to the villages of Barkåker and Sem. The village of Åsgårdstrand is partly in Tønsberg
column6: although most of the village is in Horten municipality.Tønsberg Station is 5–10 minutes walking from the main square in the city centre

column9: bars and restaurants are located. Just south of Tønsberg are the islands of Nøtterøy and Tjøme
column10: which are popular tourist destinations.The highest point in Tønsberg is Undrumsåsen at 145 meters (476 ft.). The villages of Vear and Hognes/Bjelland were merged into Tønsberg on January 1
column11: 2017. The neighboring municipality of Re will be merged into Tønsberg on or before January 1

column1: Haugar Art Museum (Haugar Vestfold Kunstmuseum) – located in the former Seamen's School in the middle of Tønsberg
column2: the brick building was built 1918–21.  The museum was established in 1993 as a foundation created by Vestfold county and municipality of Tønsberg.  The museum is a division of Vestfold Museum (Vestfoldmuseene). Haugar Vestfold Art Museum is located in the parkland between the site of the ancient assembly of Haugating and the two Viking era mounds.

column1: Foynegården – the city's best-preserved merchant's yard.  Foynegården is the site of a patrician houses from the 1700s where Svend Foyn was born in 1809.

column1: Ruins of St Michael's Church (Mikaelskirken) are still visible on top of Castle Mountain by Tønsberg Fortress. The church was mentioned among the royal chapels. It is believed to have been destroyed in 1503 when Swedish soldiers razed fortifications.
Sem Church (Sem kirke) – Vestfold's oldest stone church built before 1100 in the Romanesque style
Tønsberg Cathedral (Tønsberg domkirke) – Brick church from 1858 with pulpit from 1621 and an altarpiece from 1764.

column1: Tønsberg is the site of Oseberg Mound
column2: a Viking era burial mound. The Oseberg Ship was found in the Oseberg burial mound in 1904. This Viking era longship is now in the Viking Ship Museum in Oslo. Archaeological excavations in 1904 uncovered history's largest and richest example of craftsmanship from the Viking Age. In addition to the Oseberg Ship
column3: Oseberghaugen contained the Oseberg carriage

column11: the first wife of King Gudrød
column13: the ship was buried in blue clay and covered with stones beneath the 6-meter high Oseberg Mound.
